description: From Russian аренда́тор (arendátor), from Latin arendator, arrendator, from arendare, arrendare (“to pay rent”), from arenda (“yearly rent”), from ad + renda (whence French rente, English rent). Compare arrentation and rent.

entries.meaning: (historical) In the Russian Empire, a person who farmed local rents or revenues.
examples: The arendator collects the stated imposts merely from the boors, which amount to no great matter
